name: On Being Rigid
author: Michel Moreau
post:
The personality traits that are usually harmful are the ones that are too rigid.

By rigid, I mean traits you display in multiple scenarios as an unconscious defense mechanism, that usually result in lasting and repeating negative consequences for yourself or your relationships.

Jeffrey E. Young, a clinical psychologist, professor at Columbia University, and inventor of Schema Therapy and the term lifetraps, wrote extensively about these rigid traits, namely in his book Reinventing Your Life, in which he describes the origin of these type of traits, the way they manifest, and how to have better control over these manifestations.

If you want to better understand your human nurture, how your past influences your present personality, digging into Jeffrey E. Young’s writings is a very good starting point.

Fairwell.

name: fundamental elements of everything that exists
author: Michel Moreau
post: A finite set of non-identical entities, their motion, and the relations between the finite set of entities with motion state.

name: Life inputs that can change
author: Michel Moreau
post:
Relations

  • The time spent with specific individuals.
  • The way one behaves with specific individuals.
  • The willingness to be authentic with other individuals.
  • The willingess to understand other individuals.

Environment

  • The air one breathes.
  • The sun exposition.
  • The light exposition.
  • The physical spaces one spends time in.
  • The sounds exposition.
  • The objects one interacts with.
  • The objects one is in contact with.

Movement

  • The amount.
  • The intensity.
  • The type.

Dietetics

  • Drugs.
  • Food.
  • Water.
  • Air.
  • Skin absorption.

Sleep

  • The amount.
  • The routine pre-sleep.
  • The routine post-sleep.

Knowledge

  • The type.
  • The quantity.

Experiences

  • The type.
  • The quantity.
  • The intensity.

Cognitions

  • Habitual thoughts.
  • Non-habitual thoughts.
  • Self-limiting thoughts.
  • Self-empowering thoughts.
  • External-world-limiting thoughts.
  • External-world-empowering thoughts.
Everything that can change can change.
